reviewText: Robin and Johann are a young gay couple who decide to take a road-trip in order to spend some time together  ... they catch a train to the German countryside, where they set off by bicycle from there.  Eventually, they end up on foot, and later spend some time with a single mother and her teenage son.All of this is actually a flashback set up in the opening scene, in which Johann, as a patient at some kind of institution, is telling the story of a fox who lures a hare deep into the woods, with an implied risk of danger but the possibility of adventure. Apparently, Johann's "hare" is Robin, a willing participant in this "adventure" that may not have ended in a way he expected.  The story is told meticulously slow by the director, which will likely bore most viewers, although the photography and images are often stunning.  Based on other feedback I have read, many people get different reactions to the film and its intended message.  Your mileage may vary.DVD includes chapter stops and trailer.  Would be rated R for male nudity. I give it three stars out of five.
summary: Are you "game" for a unique film?
Title: N/A

reviewText: The OFFICIAL description of this film sates: "Johann and Robin, a young gay couple, travel to the countryside to get to know each other better. After several days of hiking, they arrive at an old farmhouse inhabited by a woman and her adolescent son. They take refuge with the welcoming family until one day they get too close for comfort and are flung out of their paradise, forcing them back into the real world."If I hadn't read that on the DVD cover, I would STILL have no clue what this film is about. It makes NO sense! This is absolutely one of the most pointless films I've ever seen!!! The acting appears to be quite good if you could only find some clue as to what they are supposed to be acting out. Some "reviewers" are not customers, but rather people associated with a film and will tell you ANYTHING to try and get you to waste your money on it. Don't be duped!Beautiful German scenery, and the farm womans son "Henri" (Denis Alevi) is quite good looking. There is very little dialogue to this film, very little point if any for making this film and absolutely NO WAY I'd ever watch this thing again!As a reviewer, all I can do is warn you not to waste your money or your time. The rest is up to you. I love films which are as this one is described to be, but this movie SUCKS!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I loved this movie! I don't care that I don't understand the end or much of anything else about it. I may figure it out someday, or I may not, but that does not in any way diminish the joy this wonderful movie gave me.I was fascinated for every one of its 75 minutes. The music alone is exhilarating, an eclectic mix including an 18th century Handel song and modern instrumentals that made me want to dance (and I am NOT a dancer). Sebastian Schlecht, who plays Johann, the darker-haired of the two lovers, is extraordinarily appealing in a quirky, understated way, and his expressions during the last ten minutes of the movie just blew me away.I never assume actors are gay, but if these two are not, then they had the best direction any two straight actors ever had, and they followed that direction with courage and dedication and talent few actors have. I believed completely in the passion and the tenderness between them, and their love scenes are some of the most erotic I have ever seen, although they are not even close to being explicit sexually.I can't get over how much better this movie is than other reviewers led me to expect.
summary: MUCH better than they're telling you
Title: N/A

reviewText: Some might call "Light Gradient" enigmatic, but incomprehensible is a more appropriate adjective.  Two young men, who happen to be lovers, take a holiday in the countryside and stumble on a farmhouse where a woman and her teenage son live and, well, not much else happens except one of the guys eats some poisonous, or maybe hallucinogenic, berries and ends up in a hospital or police station or something like that.Only 75 minutes long, the film moves at such a glacial pace that the running time seems to be twice that.  There is very little dialogue.  Instead there are long stretches where no one says or does anything.  While that approach can work quite effectively in some films ("Give Me Your Hand" comes to mind), this isn't one of them.  I certainly don't object to films that make the viewer think, but when all is said and done, I would like to have some idea of what it all meant.Still, the scenery is nice and there is a bit of good background music.Toward the end of the film one of the lovers says to the other (in the English subtitles, anyway):  "How much longer is this going to take?  This is pointless."  And that pretty much sums up "Light Gradient".
Title: N/A

reviewText: The movie "Rückenwind" literally translates from German to English as a "tailwind"; it is used to describe bicycle rides in Germany. The movie's title in English "Light Gradient" is an allegory of the story of the fox and the hare. This is the story of Henri, the farm boy who lives with his mother in a rundown farm, played by Denis Alevi, who latter becomes Johann, played by Sebastian Stiletto.You have to be familiar with the story of the fox and the hare to understand the allegory better. I will not tell it here; just look it up on your own, and hopefully you will agree with me. At the opening and closing of the movie, he tells it to staff in the hospital, probably a mental hospital. He also tells the story of the German baron whose son was lost in 1753 and found a year later in a nest of white feathers from a dismembered swam, having become a monster.The bicycles never existed. They were the product of his imagination, as it was the road robbery where they stopped two middle-aged couple riding bicycles and robed them of their food. The tent set up in the wood is another intriguing product of his imagination. Conversely, when Henri's mother gives the two grown naked men, a hose down showers in the outdoor, which she probably did to her son in younger years. Alternatively, the scene when Johann is hallucinating after eating wild poison berries and saw himself (as young Henri) being fondled by Robin, played by Eric Glob.Even the picture on the DVD of Henri in the foreground with the two men in the background is a tell all.All told, the plot was incredibly written to challenge the mind. The cinematography and music are superb; the German scenes are nostalgic, and the acting is subtle.
summary: An allegory of "The Fox and the Hare" story with a twist
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a beautiful film. So much so that I was tempted (A temptation to which I did not yield) to over-rate in an effort to mitigate the negativity."Light Gradient" is a film, very much "shown" rather than "told' or acted out. We are left to interpret the activities, long looks, and mildly kinky games between the young lovers. It's a little voyeuristic, like being there in real time. A point "shown" most vividly when they end up with a mother and her son at their farm house.The stars themselves are excellent actors,and good looking but in a very average way. Which makes the contrast between our protagonists and the angelic Henri with whom both seem taken, all the more vivid. The poignancy and angst are real, even if the cause (which is open to interpretation)is imagined.There is some plot confusion, which I believe to be the fault of poor translation, but it's minor.  Overall, the film is very well done, not slow, not boring, just different and visually, quite stunning.
Title: N/A
